main-text.text: State Capitol P.O. Box 2062 Albany, NY 12220-0062 www.its.ny.gov
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1.0 Purpose and Benefits
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy communicates the authority of the New York State Office of Information Technology Services (ITS) to oversee, direct, and issue information technology policies, standards, and guidelines.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Information technology policies, standards, and guidelines seek to:
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: · Promote innovation and deliver cost-effective IT solutions;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Ensure consistency in common technical standards and State Information Technology Resources;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Ensure adherence to the principles governing State information technology enterprise architecture and project management practices;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Protect and secure State Information Technology Resources and data;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Streamline the delivery of information or services by promoting consistency in handling, collecting, transporting, transferring, and storing data;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: Streamline the State's procurement and deployment of IT systems and infrastructure;
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Promote short or long term cost savings by reducing duplication of spending and achieving greater economies of scale across State Information Technology Resources; and
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: · Create value for IT investments to better serve citizens, businesses, State Entities, and those who visit the State of New York websites.
main-text.name: List-item

main-text.text: 2.0 Authority
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law provides ITS with the authority to establish statewide technology policies, including technology and security standards. Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117 1 , established January 2002, provides the State Chief Information Officer with the authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security and business re-engineering.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 3.0 Scope
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy applies to all "State Entities" (SE), defined as "State Government" in Executive Order 117 or "State Agencies" as defined in Section 101 of the State Technology Law. This includes employees and all third parties (such as local governments, consultants, vendors, and contractors) that use or access any Information Technology (IT) Resource for which the SE or ITS has administrative responsibility, including systems managed or hosted by third parties on behalf of the SE or ITS.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: As part of the Policy and Standard development process, ITS reserves the right to collect any information regarding the use of information technology by New York State government entities.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.0 Information Statement
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: The authority for ITS to oversee, direct, and issue policies, standards, and guidelines is provided by the State Technology Law, NYS Executive Order No. 117, and Title 6, Section 665 of the United States Code.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.1 State Technology Law
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 103(10) of the State Technology Law authorizes ITS "[t]o establish statewide technology policies, including but not limited to, preferred technology and security standards, and statewide policies, standards, programs, and services relating to the security of state government networks and Geographic Information Sytems (GIS), including the statewide coordination of geographically referenced critical infrastructure information."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Section 303 of the State Technology Law authorizes ITS to establish rules and regulations governing the use of electronic signatures and authentication.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.2 Executive Order
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Section 2 of Executive Order No. 117 provides the State Chief Information Officer, who also serves as Director of ITS (formerly known as the Office for Technology), the
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 1 All references to Executive Order 117 refer to that which was originally issued by Governor George E. Pataki on January 28, 2002 and continued by Executive Order 5 issued by Governor Eliot Spitzer on January 1, 2007, Executive Order 9 issued by Governor David A. Patterson on June 18, 2008, Executive Order 2 issued by Governor Andrew M. Cuomo on January 1, 2011 and Executive Order 6 issued by Governor Kathy Hochul on October 8, 2021.
main-text.name: Footnote

main-text.text: Page 2 of 4
main-text.name: Page-footer

main-text.text: authority to oversee, direct and coordinate the establishment of information technology policies, protocols and standards for State government, including hardware, software, security and business re-engineering.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: Executive Order No. 117 defines "'State government' to include "all State agencies, departments, offices, divisions, boards, bureaus, commissions and other entities over which the Governor has executive power and the State University of New York, City University of New York and all public benefit corporations the heads of which are appointed by the Governor; provided, however, that the powers and duties of the Chief Information Officer shall extend to business and administrative functions of such universities common to State government."
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 4.3 United States Code
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Title 6, Section 665 of the United States Code and accompanying guidance outlines the process for registering an Internet GOV Domain and the naming conventions for such domains. The guidance authorizes the highest ranking information technology official to register and oversee an government entity's Internet GOV Domain. As the State's highest ranking information technology official, the State Chief information Officer is responsible for registering and overseeing State Entity's Internet GOV Domains.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 5.0 Compliance
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy shall take effect upon publication. Compliance is required with all enterprise policies and standards. ITS may amend its policies and standards at any time; compliance with amended policies and standards is required.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 6.0 Definitions of Key Terms
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: Except for terms defined in this policy, all terms shall have the meanings found in http://www.its.ny.gov/glossary.
main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.name: Text

main-text.name: Text

main-text.text: 8.0 Revision History
main-text.name: Section-header

main-text.text: This policy shall be reviewed at least once every two years to ensure relevancy.
main-text.name: Text
